--- title: "Data manipulation and visualisation" subtitle: "Marine Ecosystem Dynamics" author: "Kinlan Jan, Baptiste Serandour" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: "../../assets/images/background.svg" data-background-position: top format: revealjs: fontsize: 25pt theme: dark slide-number: true show-slide-number: all chalkboard: true logo: "../../assets/images/SU_logo.png" --- ## Plan for today's lecture ::: {layout-ncol="5"} ![](../../assets/images/tidyverse.svg) ![](../../assets/images/pipe.svg) ![](../../assets/images/tidyr.svg) ![](../../assets/images/dplyr.svg) ![](../../assets/images/ggplot2.svg) ::: - Introduction to `tidyverse` - Pipe the data using `magrittr` - Clean the data using `tidyr` - Arrange the data using `dplyr` - Plot using `ggplot2` ## Tidyverse ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} - `tidyverse` is a [collection of packages](https://www.tidyverse.org/packages/) - It is now a standard in data analysis - It is easier to read and keep track of what is happening with the pipe operator `%>%` ::: aside The book is available [online](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html) ::: ::: ::: ## Pipe the data using `magrittr` `%>%` takes the data from the left and place it to the right - `x %>% function()` = `function(x)` ::: columns ::: {.column width="\"50%"} Without the pipe operator: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris_subset <- iris[, c("Species", "Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width")] iris_subset$Sepal_Ratio <- iris_subset$Sepal.Length / iris_subset$Sepal.Width aggregate(Sepal_Ratio ~ Species, data = iris_subset, FUN = function(x) c(Average_ratio = mean(x), standard_deviation = sd(x))) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="\"50%"} With the pipe operator: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(magrittr) iris %>% dplyr::select(Species, Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width) %>% dplyr::mutate(Sepal_Ratio = Sepal.Length/Sepal.Width) %>% dplyr::group_by(Species)%>% dplyr::summarise(Average_ratio = mean(Sepal_Ratio), standard_deviation = sd(Sepal_Ratio)) ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: aside R 4.1.0 introduced a native pipe operator, `|>` ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} A table is tidy if: - Each variable is in its own column - Each observation is in its own row ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Key functions: - `pivot_longer` - `pivot_wider` - `unite` - `separate` ::: ::: ::: {style="text-align:center"} ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` - `iris` example ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species id
5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 1
4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 2
4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 3
4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 4
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris %<>% dplyr::mutate(id = 1:150) iris |> head(4) ``` ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` - `pivot_longer` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Species id Parameter Size
setosa 1 Sepal.Length 5.1
setosa 1 Sepal.Width 3.5
setosa 1 Petal.Length 1.4
setosa 1 Petal.Width 0.2
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} long_iris <- iris |> tidyr::pivot_longer(1:4, names_to = "Parameter", values_to = "Size") long_iris |> head(4) ``` ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` - `separate` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Species id Organ Measure Size
setosa 1 Sepal Length 5.1
setosa 1 Sepal Width 3.5
setosa 1 Petal Length 1.4
setosa 1 Petal Width 0.2
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sep_iris <- long_iris |> tidyr::separate(Parameter, into = c("Organ", "Measure")) sep_iris |> head(4) ``` ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` - `pivot_wider` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Species id Measure Sepal Petal
setosa 1 Length 5.1 1.4
setosa 1 Width 3.5 0.2
setosa 2 Length 4.9 1.4
setosa 2 Width 3.0 0.2
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wide_iris <- sep_iris |> tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = "Organ", values_from = "Size") wide_iris |> head(4) ``` ::: ## Tidy the data with `tidyr` - `unite` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Species id Measure Sepal/Petal
setosa 1 Length 5.1/1.4
setosa 1 Width 3.5/0.2
setosa 2 Length 4.9/1.4
setosa 2 Width 3/0.2
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unite_iris <- wide_iris |> tidyr::unite(col = "Sepal/Petal", c(Sepal, Petal), sep = "/") unite_iris |> head(4) ``` ::: ## Arrange the data with `dyplr` `dplyr` simplifies the data manipulation with self-explanatory functions: - `filter` observations based on their values - `mutate` a new column as a function of others - `select` variables based on their names - `group_by` variable - `summarise` the data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} iris %>% dplyr::filter(Petal.Length >= 1.4) %>% dplyr::mutate(Sepal_Ratio = Sepal.Length/Sepal.Width) %>% dplyr::select(Species, Sepal_Ratio) %>% # equaivalent to select(-c(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width)) dplyr::group_by(Species) %>% dplyr::summarise(Average_ratio = mean(Sepal_Ratio), standard_deviation = sd(Sepal_Ratio)) ``` ::: ## Data visulalisation It is very important to look at the data. Totally different data might have similar statistics... ::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
statistics value
mean_x 54.27
mean_y 47.83
sd_x 16.77
sd_y 26.94
````` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: aside [datasauRus](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/datasauRus/vignettes/Datasaurus.html){.smaller} ::: ## Visualise the data with `ggplot2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-0-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(x = iris$Sepal.Length, y = iris$Sepal.Width) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-01-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width)) + geom_point() ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Visualise the data with `ggplot2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} species_palette <- c("#F8766D", "#00BA38", "#619CFF") size_vector <- iris$Petal.Width plot(x = iris$Sepal.Length, y = iris$Sepal.Width, col = species_palette[iris$Species], bg = species_palette[iris$Species], pch = 21, cex = size_vector, xlim = c(min(iris$Sepal.Length), max(iris$Sepal.Length)), ylim = c(min(iris$Sepal.Width), max(iris$Sepal.Width)), xlab = "Sepal.Length", ylab = "Sepal.Width") legend("topright", legend = levels(iris$Species), col = species_palette, pch = 21, pt.bg = species_palette, cex = 1.2, title = "Species") grid(lwd = 1, lty = "dotted") ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, fill = Species, size = Petal.Width)) + geom_point(shape = 21, col = 1) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Grammar of graphic (`gg`) ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment .highlight-red} - Data - Aesthetics - Visual characteristics (e.g., x, y, size) - Geometry - How to represent the data (e.g., lines, point, boxplot) ::: - Statistics - What statistics to show - Facets - Split the data - Coordinates - Position of the geometry - Themes - Visual changes ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = , mapping = aes()) + geom_() ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Let's plot using `ggplot2` - *Data* ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = iris) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-4-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Let's plot using `ggplot2` - *Geometry* ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="4"} ggplot(data = iris, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width)) + geom_point(mapping = aes(col = Species)) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-7-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Let's plot using `ggplot2` - *Statistics* ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="5|6,7,8"} ggplot(data = iris, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width)) + geom_point(mapping = aes(col = Species)) + stat_smooth(method = "lm") + stat_smooth(method = "lm", mapping = aes(col = Species, fill = Species)) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/bag-8-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Let's plot using `ggplot2` - <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
